poem:
Greenland, The First and Last

Where Earth drew its first breath,
in the cradle of ancient stone,
the young now trace the edge of loss,
winds whispering elegies of ice.
Here, dawns still shiver with the newness of life,
but footfalls echo in a warming world—
a quiet witness
to the melting sighs of time.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Last Human review – despair and hope for Greenland youth in crosshairs of climate peril A love letter to her Greenland home, Ivola Frank’s stirring documentary explores the paradoxes of this beautiful and remote island. According to a groundbreaking study by geologist Minik Rosing, it is where life on Earth began, among the rock formations that have existed for nearly 4bn years. At the same time, the residents of Greenland are also bearing witness". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
